name: Ḫattušili I
title: Hittite king
quote: Wash me well, hold me to your breast, protect me from the earth (lying against) your breast.
context: probably addressing his wife or favorite concubine and expressing his fear of death while being gravely ill

name: ("שְׁלֹף חַרְבְּךָ וּמוֹתְתֵנִי--פֶּן-יֹאמְרוּ לִי
title: אִשָּׁה הֲרָגָתְהוּ") — Abimelech, king of Shechem
quote: Draw thy sword, and slay me, that men say not of me, A woman slew him.
context: Mortally wounded in battle by a stone thrown by a woman, he asked his armor-bearer to kill him

name: ("תָּמוֹת נַפְשִׁי עִם-פְּלִשְׁתִּים") — Samson
title: judge of the Israelites
quote: Let me die with the Philistines.
context: prior to bringing down pillars of the Philistine temple and killing 3000 people along with himself

name: ("שְׁלֹף חַרְבְּךָ וְדָקְרֵנִי בָהּ
title: פֶּן-יָבוֹאוּ הָעֲרֵלִים הָאֵלֶּה וּדְקָרֻנִי וְהִתְעַלְּלוּ-בִי") — Saul, king of Israel
quote: Draw thy sword, and thrust me through therewith; lest these uncircumcised come and thrust me through, and abuse me.
context: to his servant during the Battle of Mount Gilboa

name: Anacharsis
title: Scythian philosopher
quote: My reputation carried me safe through Greece, but the envy it excited at home has been my ruin.
context: mortally wounded with an arrow by his brother, King Caduidas

name: Chilon of Sparta
title: philosopher
quote: On a certain occasion, I chanced to be one of three who sat in judgment on one of my own good friends, who, according to the laws, should have been punished with death. I was greatly embarrassed. One of two things was inevitable—either to violate the law or condemn my friend. After careful consideration, I devised this expedient. I delivered with such address all the most plausible arguments in behalf of the accused, that my two colleagues found no difficulty in acquitting him, and yet I, myself, condemned him to death without assigning any reason for my conduct. Thus I discharged two duties, those of friend and judge; yet I feel in my conscience something which makes me doubt whether my conduct was not criminal.
context: speaking to his friends before his death

name: Pythagoras
title: Ionian Greek philosopher and founder of Pythagoreanism (495 BC), refusing to escape with his students from the Crotonians through a fava bean field
quote: It is better to perish here than to kill all these poor beans.

name: ("वयधम्मा सङखार्आ अप्पमादेन सम्पादेथा") — Siddhārtha Gautama Buddha
title: Shakya sage who founded Buddhism
quote: All compounded things are subject to vanish. Strive with earnestness.

name: Confucius
title: Chinese philosopher who founded Confucianism (479 BC)
quote: Heaven has turned against me. No wise ruler arises, and no one in the Empire wishes to make me his teacher. The hour of my death has come.

name: Heraclitus
title: Greek philosopher
quote: Can you turn rainy weather into dry?
context: asking his physicians for relief from dropsy

name: Pericles
title: Greek statesman (429 BC), discussing with his friends what his greatest accomplishment had been
quote: For, no Athenian, through my means, ever wore mourning.

name: Anaxagoras
title: Greek philosopher
quote: Give the boys a holiday.
context: in response to citizens of Lampsacus asking how they could honor his memory

name: Theramenes
title: Athenian statesman (404 BC), after swallowing poison hemlock which he had been condemned to drink by Critias
quote: This to the fair Critias.

name: ("Κρίτων
title: ἔφη, τῷ Ἀσκληπιῷ ὀφείλομεν ἀλεκτρυόνα· ἀλλὰ ἀπόδοτε καὶ μὴ ἀμελήσητε") — Socrates, Greek philosopher (399 BC), just before his death by ingestion of poison hemlock which he was forced to drink as a death sentence
quote: Crito, we owe a cock to Asclepius. Please, don't forget to pay the debt.

name: Anaxibius
title: Spartan admiral (388 BC), before being killed in Athenian ambush
quote: Men, it is good for me to die on this spot, where honor bids me; but for you, yonder your path lies. Hurry and save yourselves before the enemy can close with us.

name: Epaminondas
title: Greek general and statesman of Thebes (362 BC). He pulled out the weapon with which he had been impaled in battle once he heard the enemy was fleeing.
quote: Then I die happy.

name: Darius III
title: Achaemenid King of Kings of Persia (330 BC), to a man who gave him water as he was dying
quote: But Alexander, whose kindness to my mother, my wife, and my children I hope the gods will recompense, will doubtless thank you for your humanity to me. Tell him, therefore, in token of my acknowledgement, I give him this right hand.

name: ("Quid mihi nocebunt ferārum dentes nihil sentienti.") — Diogenes
title: Greek Cynic philosopher (323 BC), asking for his body to be thrown outside the city wall for animals to eat
quote: How can the teeth of wild beasts hurt me, without consciousness?

name: ("Τῷ κρατίστῳ") — Alexander the Great
title: conqueror and king of Macedonia
quote: To the strongest.
context: when asked to whom his vast empire should belong after his death

name: Demosthenes
title: Greek statesman and orator (12 October 322 BC), to Archias of Thurii; Demosthenes had taken poison to avoid arrest by Archias
quote: Now, as soon as you please you may commence the part of Creon in the tragedy, and cast out this body of mine unburied. But, O gracious Neptune, I, for my part, while I am yet alive, arise up and depart out of this sacred place; though Antipater and the Macedonians have not left so much as thy temple unpolluted.

name: Crates of Thebes
title: Cynic philosopher
quote: Ah! poor hump-back! thy many long years are at last conveying thee to the tomb; thou shalt soon see the palace of Pluto.
context: surveying himself when about to die

name: Epicurus
title: Greek philosopher (270 BC); the majority of his writings are now lost
quote: Now, farewell, and remember all my words!

name: Zeno of Citium
title: Greek philosopher and founder of Stoicism
quote: I come, I come, why dost thou call for me?
context: quoting Aeschylus' play Niobe and striking the ground with his hand after sustaining a minor injury, which he considered a sign that he was about to die. He then killed himself

name: Agis IV
title: king of Sparta (241 BC), prior to execution by strangulation
quote: Weep not, friend, for me, who dies innocent, by the lawless act of wicked men. My condition is much better than theirs.

name: Cratesiclea
title: queen of Sparta (219 BC), after seeing the children of her family executed prior to her own execution
quote: O children, whither are you going?

name: Aratus of Sicyon
title: Hellenistic Greek politician and military commander (213 BC), after expectorating blood while allegedly being slowly poisoned on the orders of Philip V of Macedon, his former friend
quote: These, O Cephalon, are the wages of a king's love.

name: ("Μή μου τοὺς κύκλους τάραττε!") — Archimedes
title: Greek mathematician
quote: Do not disturb my circles!
context: to a Roman soldier who interrupted his geometric experiments during the capture of Syracuse, whereupon the soldier killed him

name: Chrysippus
title: Greek philosopher
quote: Go and give the ass a drink of wine to wash down the figs.
context: before dying of laughter

name: Philopoemen
title: Greek general and statesman (183 BC), sent a cup of poison to kill himself after being captured in battle. He asked the messenger with the poison about his cavalry and was told that most of them had escaped.
quote: It is well that we have not been every way unfortunate.

name: ("Liberemus diuturna cura populum Romanum
title: quando mortem senis exspectare longum censent.") — Hannibal, Carthaginian general
quote: Let us ease the Roman people of their continual care, who think it long to await the death of an old man.
context: in a suicide note

name: Ennius
title: writer and poet of the Roman Republic
quote: Let no one weep for me, or celebrate my funeral with mourning; for I still live, as I pass to and fro through the mouths of men.
context: ; lines dictated to be engraved on his memorial. Only fragments of his works now survive

name: Jugurtha
title: king of Numidia (104 BC), being lowered by the Romans into a damp dungeon to starve to death
quote: It is a cold bath you give me.

name: Marcus Livius Drusus
title: Roman politician and reformer (91 BC), after being stabbed by unknown assassin
quote: When will the republic find a citizen like me?

name: Alexander Jannaeus
title: king of Judea
quote: Fear not true Pharisees, but greatly fear painted Pharisees.
context: to his wife

name: Monime
title: wife of Mithridates VI (72/71 BC), after failing to hang herself by her crown's strings in fulfillment of her death sentence
quote: O wretched head-band!—not able to help me even in this small thing!

name: Dumnorix
title: Gallic chieftain,
quote: I am free and the subject of a free state.
context: before being killed by Roman cavalry

name: Pompey
title: Roman general and statesman (28 September 48 BC), to Lucius Septimius, one of his assassins
quote: I am not mistaken, surely, in believing you to have been formerly my fellow-soldier.

name: ("Imperator se bene habet") — Metellus Scipio
title: Roman senator and military commander (46 BC), before committing suicide to evade capture following his defeat in the Battle of Hippo Regius.
quote: The imperator is doing well.

name: ("Καὶ σὺ
title: τέκνον") — Julius Caesar, Roman dictator (15 March 44 BC), discovering that his stepson Brutus was among his murderers.
quote: You too, my child?

name: Decimus Junius Brutus Albinus
title: Roman general and politician, conspirator in Julius Caesar's assassination (September 43 BC), quoting from Euripides prior to execution
quote: O wretched virtue! thou art a bare name! I mistook thee for a substance; but thou thyself art the slave of fortune.

name: ("Accede
title: veterane, et, si hoc saltim potes recte facere, incide cervicem [...] 'quid, si ad me inquit primum venissetis?") — Cicero, Roman statesman (7 December 43 BC), facing an assassin sent by an enemy
quote: I go no further: approach, veteran soldier, and, if you can at least do so much properly, sever this neck. [...] What would you have done had you come to me as your first victim?

name: Gaius Cassius Longinus
title: Roman senator and general, one of Julius Caesar's assassins (3 October 42 BC), erroneously believing his comrade Titinius had been captured by Mark Antony's forces at the Battle of Philippi. Cassius then killed himself.
quote: Through too much fondness of life, I have lived to endure the sight of my friend taken by the enemy before my face.

name: Marcus Junius Brutus
title: Roman senator and assassin of Julius Caesar (23 October 42 BC), after defeat at the Battle of Philippi. He then bade his friends farewell before killing himself.
quote: Yes, indeed, we must fly; but not with our feet, but with our hands.

name: Mark Antony
title: Roman politician and general (1 August 30 BC); to Cleopatra before his suicide
quote: You must not pity me in this last turn of fate. You should rather be happy in the remembrance of our love, and in the recollection that of all men I was once the most famous and the most powerful, and now, at the end, have fallen not dishonorably, a Roman by a Roman vanquished.

name: ("Τόσο εδώ!") — Cleopatra
title: pharaoh of Egypt (12 August 30 BC), right before she reportedly committed suicide by letting an asp bite her
quote: Here thou art, then!

name: Charmion
title: servant to Cleopatra (12 August 30 BC), when one of Emperor Augustus' men asked her, "Was this well done of your lady, Charmion?" She then fell dead.
quote: Extremely well, and as became the descendant of so many kings.

name: Virgil
title: Roman poet (21 September 19 BC)
quote: Death twitches my ear. 'Live,' he says. 'I am coming.'

name: ("Acta est fabula
title: plaudite.") — Augustus, First Roman Emperor (19 August 14 AD)
quote: Have I played the part well? Then applaud, as I exit.

name: ("τετέλεσται. / πάτερ
title: εἰς χεῖράς σου παρατίθεμαι τὸ πνεῦμά μου.") — Jesus, founder of Christianity
quote: It is finished. \ Father, into thy hands I commend my spirit.
context: right before his death by crucifixion

name: Saint Stephen
title: early Christian deacon and protomartyr
quote: Lord Jesus, receive my spirit. Lord, lay not this sin to their charge.
context: while being stoned to death

name: Caligula
title: Roman emperor (24 January 41 AD), after being fatally stabbed
quote: I am still alive!

name: ("Non dolet
title: Paete!") — Arria, Roman woman (42 AD), to her husband, Aulus Caecina Paetus. He had been condemned to death but given permission to kill himself; when he hesitated to do so, his wife stabbed herself first and handed the dagger to him.
quote: It is not painful, Pætus.

name: Agrippina the Younger
title: mother of Nero (23 March 59 AD), to her murderer
quote: Strike here! Level your rage against the womb which gave birth to such a monster.

name: Lucan
title: Roman poet (30 April 65 AD), forced to commit suicide after joining in a conspiracy against Nero. He died quoting lines from his own epic poem Pharsalia.
quote: Asunder flies the man— / No single wound the gaping rupture seems, / Where trickling crimson flows the tender streams; / But from an opening horrible and wide / A thousand vessels pour the bursting tide: / At once the winding channel's course was broke, / Where wandering life her mazy journey took.

name: ("Sero... Haec est fides") — Nero
title: Roman emperor (9 June 68 AD), to a soldier trying to save him after his suicide
quote: Too late; is this your fidelity?

name: ("Ferirent si ita e republica videretur.") — Galba
title: Roman emperor (15 January 69 AD), prior to beheading by supporters of Otho
quote: Strike, if it be for the Romans' good.

name: Otho
title: Roman emperor (16 April 69 AD), to a freedman, prior to committing suicide
quote: Go and show yourself to the soldiers, lest they cut you to pieces for being accessory to my death.

name: Vitellius
title: Roman emperor (22 December 69 AD), prior to his killing on the Gemonian stairs
quote: Yet I was once your Emperor.

name: ("Vae
title: puto, deus fio... imperatorem stantem oportet mori.") — Vespasian, Roman emperor (24 June 79 AD), ironically alluding to the Roman practice of posthumously deifying former emperors, before he collapsed and died when attempting to stand up.
quote: Woe, I think I'm turning into a god... An emperor should die on his feet.

name: Pliny the Elder
title: Roman military commander and author (October 79 AD), after being advised to turn back from Herculaneum during the eruption of Mount Vesuvius.
quote: Fortune favors the bold. Make for where Pomponianus is.

name: Titus
title: Roman emperor (13 September 81 AD)
quote: My life is taken from me, though I have done nothing to deserve it; for there is no action of mine of which I should repent, but one.

name: ("שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל יְהוָה אֱלֹהֵינוּ יְהוָה אֶחָד") — Rabbi Akiva
title: Jewish scholar and sage (28 September 135 AD), reciting the Shema Yisrael while being executed by the Romans
quote: Hear, O Israel! The Lord is our God! The Lord is One!

name: Hadrian
title: Roman emperor (10 July 138 AD)
quote: O my poor soul, whither art thou going?

name: Polycarp
title: Christian bishop of Smyrna (155 AD), prior to martyrdom by burning and spearing
quote: O Lord God Almighty, Father of Thy well-beloved Son, Jesus Christ, by whom we have received knowledge of Thee; God of angels, powers, and every creature that lives before Thee; I thank Thee that Thou hast graciously thought me worthy of this day and hour, that I may receive a portion in the number of Thy martyrs, and drink of Christ's cup, for the resurrection of both soul and body unto life eternal, in the incorruptibleness of the Holy Spirit. Among them may I be admitted this day, as an acceptable sacrifice, as Thou, O true and faithful God, hast prepared, foreshown, and accomplished. Wherefore, I praise Thee for all Thy mercies. I bless Thee. I glorify Thee, with Jesus Christ, Thy beloved Son, the Eternal, to Whom, with Thee and the Holy Spirit, be glory now and forever.

name: ("Æquanimitas.") — Antoninus Pius
title: Roman emperor (7 March 161 AD), giving the password for the night-watch
quote: Equanimity.

name: Demonax
title: Greek Cynic philosopher
quote: You may go home, the show is over.

name: Marcus Aurelius
title: Roman emperor and philosopher (17 March 180 AD)
quote: Go to the rising sun, for I am setting. Think more of death than of me.

name: Didius Julianus
title: Roman emperor (2 June 193 AD), to his assassin.
quote: But what evil have I done? Whom have I killed?

name: ("Adeste
title: si quid mihi restat agendum.") — Septimius Severus, Roman emperor (4 February 211 AD)
quote: Hurry, if anything remains for me to do.

name: ("Assatus est; jam versa et manduca.") — Saint Lawrence
title: Christian deacon (10 August 258 AD), while being burned alive on a gridiron
quote: I am roasted,—now turn me, and eat me.

name: Cyprian
title: Christian bishop of Carthage and martyr (14 September 258 AD), sentenced to death by beheading
quote: God be thanked.

name: Plotinus
title: Hellenistic philosopher (270 AD)
quote: I am making my last effort to return that which is divine in me to that which is divine in the Universe.

name: Anthony the Great
title: Christian monk from Egypt (17 January 356 AD)
quote: And let my word be kept secret by you, so that no one knows the place but you alone. For in the resurrection of the dead I shall receive my body incorruptible once again from the Savior. Distribute my clothing. To Bishop Athanasius give the one sheepskin and the cloak on which I lie, which he gave to me new, but I have by now worn out. And to Bishop Serapion give the other sheepskin, and you keep the hair garment. And now God preserve you, children, for Antony is leaving and is with you no longer.

name: Marcus of Arethusa
title: Christian bishop and martyr (362 AD), hung up in a honey-smeared basket for bees to sting him to death
quote: How am I advanced, despising you that are upon the earth!

name: ("Vicisti
title: Galilaee.") — Julian, Roman emperor (26 June 363 AD), mortally wounded in battle. He had rejected Christianity in favor of paganism; according to some accounts, he was assassinated by a Christian.
quote: And yet Thou hast conquered, O Galilean!

name: Saint Monica
title: mother of Augustine of Hippo (387 AD)
quote: In peace I will sleep with Him and take my rest.

name: Severus of Ravenna
title: Bishop of Ravenna
quote: My dear one, with whom I lived in love so long, make room for me, for this is my grave, and in death we shall not be divided.
context: According to a traditional story, Severus laid himself in his family tomb alongside his dead wife and daughter, then died

name: Ambrose
title: Bishop of Milan (4 April 397 AD), when Simplician was mentioned as his possible successor
quote: Old though he be, he is the best of all.

name: Martin of Tours
title: third bishop of Tours (8 November 397 AD), to the Devil"Glory to God for all things! Amen." ("δόξα τῷ θεῷ πάντων ἕνεκεν") — John Chrysostom, Early Church Father and Archbishop of Constantinople (14 September 407), while traveling deeper into exile
quote: What dost thou here, thou cruel beast?

name: ("მე ესე რა წარვალ წინაშე ღმრთისა ჩემისა
title: და ვმადლობ სახელსა მისსა, რამეთუ არა დამაკლო გამორჩეულთა წმიდათა მისთა. აწ გამცნებ თქუენ, რათა მტკიცედ სარწმუნოებასა ზედა სდგეთ და ეძიებდეთ ქრისტესთჳს სიკუდილსა სახელსა მისსა ზედა, რათა წარუვალი დიდება მოიგოთ. მე ჴორციელებრითა დიდებითა გადიდენ თქუენ ნათესავთა ჩემთა. და სახლსა ჩუენსა ნუ შეურაცხჰყოფთ, და სიყუარულსა ბერძენთასა ნუ დაუტეობთ".) — Vakhtang I, Georgian monarch (502/22), to his son Dachi.
quote: And me as I am going towards the God of mine, and I thank His name, as the Lord gave me everything bless His name. And I am telling you, to stand firm on your faith and to search for death for Christ for His name and you will find the permanent glory. I for my life glorified you and all of our race. And do not insult our home and do not abandon the love of the Greeks.

name: Columba
title: Irish abbot and missionary evangelist (8 June 597), ceasing to transcribe a Psalter
quote: Here must I stop. What follows, let Baithen write.

name: Phocas
title: Eastern Roman emperor (3 October 610), to his successor Heraclius before being executed
quote: Will you govern it any better?

name: ("اللَّهُمَّ الرَّفِيقَ الأَعْلَى") or :("الصلاة ، الصلاة!  واتقوا الله في من يملك يمينكم") — Muhammad
title: Prophet of God in Islam (8 June 632)
quote: Oh God, the Friend Most High!" or "The prayer, the prayer! And fear Allah with regard to those whom your right hands possess

name: Goar of Aquitaine
title: priest and hermit (6 July 649), dying in Oberwesel, Austrasia
quote: Here shall my Saviour be known in all the simplicity of his doctrines. Ah! would that I might witness it; but I have seen those things in a vision. But I faint! I am weary! My earthly journey is finished! Receive my blessing. Go! and be kind one to another.

name: Xuanzang
title: Chinese Buddhist monk, scholar, traveler and translator (5 February 664)
quote: I desire that whatever merits I may have gained by good works may fall upon other people. May I be born again with them in the heaven of the blessed, be admitted to the family of Mi-le, and serve the Buddha of the future, who is full of kindness and affection. When I descend again upon earth, to pass through other forms of existence, I desire at every new birth to fulfill my duties toward Buddha, and arrive at the end to the highest perfect intelligence.

name: Yŏn Kaesomun
title: military dictator and generalissimo of Goguryeo
quote: You brothers must get along like fish and water and never fight each other for titles. If not, you will surely become the laughingstock of our neighbors.
context: to his sons

name: Bede
title: English Benedictine monk (26 May 735); to a scribe to whom he was dictating a translation of the Gospel of John
quote: You speak truth, all is finished now. Glory to God.

name: Charlemagne
title: European monarch (28 January 814), quoting Jesus
quote: Lord, into Thy hands I commend my spirit.

name: ("Huz! huz!") — Louis the Pious
title: King of the Franks (20 June 840), after turning his face to the wall before dying
quote: Out! out!

name: ("Gnyðja mundu grísir
title: ef þeir vissi, hvat inn gamli þyldi.") — Ragnar Lodbrok, semi-legendary Norse chieftain
quote: The piglets would grunt if they knew how the old boar is suffering!
context: after being cast into a snakepit by King Ælla of Northumbria

name: Alfred the Great
title: king of the Anglo-Saxons (26 October 899), to his son, Edward the Elder
quote: Thou my dear son, set thee now beside me, and I will deliver thee true instructions. My son, I feel that my hour is coming. My countenance is wan. My days are almost done. We must now part. I shall to another world, and thou shalt be left alone in all my wealth. I pray thee (for thou art my dear child) strive to be a father, and a lord to thy people. Be thou the children's father, and the widow's friend. Comfort thou the poor, and shelter the weak; and, with all thy might, right that which is wrong. And, son, govern thyself, by law; then shall the Lord love thee, and God above all things shall be thy reward. Call thou upon him to advise thee in all thy need, and so shall he help thee, the better to compass that which thou wouldest.

name: Abd al-Rahman III
title: first Caliph of Córdoba (15 October 961)
quote: I have now reigned above fifty years in victory or peace; beloved by my subjects, dreaded by my enemies, and respected by my allies. Riches and honors, power and pleasure, have waited on my call, nor does any earthly blessing appear to have been wanting to my felicity. In this situation, I have diligently numbered the days of pure and genuine happiness which have fallen to my lot: they amount to Fourteen:—O man! place not thy confidence in this present world!

name: ("Christianorum carnes paganis dentibus conterendas dare. Ego equidem id faciam
title: si quod paupertas ad vitem paraverat, vestries hoc morsibus abutendum tradam.") — Ælfheah of Canterbury, Archbishop of Canterbury
quote: You urge me in vain. I am not the man to provide Christian flesh for pagan teeth to devour, and it would be so acting if I delivered unto you that which the poor have laid by for their subsistence.
context: refusing to pay ransom before being killed by his Danish captors

name: Siward
title: Earl of Northumbria
quote: How shameful it is that I, who could not die in so many battles, should have been saved for the ignominious death of a cow! At least clothe me in my impenetrable breastplate, gird me with my sword, place my helmet on my head, my shield in my left hand, my gilded battle-axe in my right, that I, the bravest of soldiers, may die like a soldier.
context: dying of dysentery

name: ("Dilexi iustitiam et odivi iniquitatem propterea morior in exilio.") — Pope Gregory VII (25 May 1085)
quote: I have loved justice and hated iniquity; therefore I die in exile.
context: in exile in Salerno due to his conflicts with Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor

name: William the Conqueror
title: King of England
quote: Then to our blessed Lady Mary, the mother of God, I commend myself. May she, by her holy intercessions, reconcile me to our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ. God be merciful to—
context: after hearing bell ringing Prime

name: Berengar of Tours
title: French Christian theologian
quote: I shall not long hesitate between conscience and the Pope, for I shall soon appear in the presence of God, to be acquitted, I hope; to be condemned, I fear.
context: dying in ascetic solitude on the island of Saint-Cosme near Tours

name: William II of England (2 August 1100)
quote: Shoot, Walter, in the devil's name!
context: to Walter Tirel, who allegedly shot the king in a hunting accident

name: Anselm of Canterbury
title: Archbishop of Canterbury
quote: Yes, if it be His will, I shall obey it willingly. But were He to let me stay with you a little longer till I have resolved a problem about the origin of the soul, I would gladly accept the boon; for I do not know whether anyone will work it out when I am gone. If I could but eat, I think I should pick up a little strength. I feel no pain in any part of my body; only I cannot retain nourishment, and that exhausts me.

name: ("Plus volui nocere quam potui.") — Ranulf Flambard
title: Norman Bishop of Durham and government minister
quote: I wished to do more harm than I could.

name: ("Je ne sais.") — Peter Abelard
title: French philosopher and theologian
quote: I don't know.

name: Bernard of Clairvaux
title: Burgundian abbot
quote: May God's will be done.
